instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
Unit posts but display stays black. Checked with flashlight but can't see anything.
Tested with another screen and same issue.

Still new at this so tracking an issue through the schematics is still a little difficult. That said I took the following readings:

[B]<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>[/B]
Pin 1: 0.53mv and dropping constantly [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 12.6V?)[/COLOR]
Pin 2: 0.26mv and dropping constantly (same value as pin 1 when I check back and forth)[COLOR=#FF0000] (should be 12.6V?)[/COLOR]
Pin 3: 12.46 v [COLOR=#008000](correct)[/COLOR]
Pin 4: 12.57 v [COLOR=#008000](correct)[/COLOR]
Pin 5: 0.36 mv and dropping constantly [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 12.6V?)[/COLOR]
Pin 6: 0.26 mv and dropping slowly [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 12.6V?)[/COLOR]

[B]L7710[/B]
Pin 1: 0.18.1 mv steady (measured at <CAPACITOR>C7710</CAPACITOR> pin 1) [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 12.6V?)[/COLOR]
Pin 2: 0.15.8 mv steady (measured at probe point above it) [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 45V?)[/COLOR]

[B]<TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>[/B]
Pin 1: 0.08.4 mv
Pin 2: 0.08.3 mv
Pin 3: 0.07.5 mv slowly rising
Pin 4: 0
Pin 5: 0.11.8 mv slowly rising
Unsure what any of these should read as schematic doesn't mention voltages. I am assuming pin 5 should shoot out 40+V?

[B]<CHIP>U7701</CHIP>[/B]
Unable to read, I ordered better multimeter probes from Louis' site :)

[B]J8300[/B]
Pin 1: 0 [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 55V?)[/COLOR]

[B]L8300[/B]
Pin 1: 0 [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 5V?)[/COLOR]
Pin 2: 0 [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 5V?)[/COLOR]

[B]<CHIP>U8300</CHIP>[/B]
Pin 1: 0 (can't find what this should read)
Pin 2: 5 [COLOR=#008000](correct)[/COLOR]
Pin 3: 5 [COLOR=#008000](correct?)[/COLOR]
Pin 4: 0 [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 5V?)[/COLOR]
Pin 5: 0 [COLOR=#FF0000](should be 5V?)[/COLOR]
Pin 6: 0

[B]<RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>[/B]
Pin 1: 5 v [COLOR=#008000](correct)[/COLOR]
Pin 2: 4.80 v [COLOR=#008000](correct?)[/COLOR]

[COLOR=#000000]Lots of question marks as I am not experienced enough to be certain about anything.

At this point I start to lose track a little. Am I going in the right direction/measuring the relevant points?
I would like to find a solution at some point but today I'm just trying to learn how to read the roadmap better/properly :)[/COLOR]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> / L7710 / <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR> are all inactive because the system is probably not activating the backlight at all.

The system needs to "talk" to the display before it will activate the backlight, since there is no picture we can conclude the talking isn't going well
To verify this see how the <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>EDP_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> signal is doing. This signal is most likely low, so the backlight is not being enabled.

Since <CHIP>U8300</CHIP>'s Pin 1 is LOW the display is not getting its 5V power signal, this is the issue we should look into.

How does the connector look like? Are all the pins making contact to the board?
Check if <RESISTOR>R8300</RESISTOR> is alright

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
Thanks smiba,

[B]<RESISTOR>R8300</RESISTOR>[/B]
Pin 1: 0V
Pin 2: 0V

J8300 looks good, all pins are connected properly.

To check <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> I need to measure pins on <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> which I currently can't do with the meter probes I have. Should be able to check later this week though.
Using the probe point and <RESISTOR>R7756</RESISTOR> to measure though gives me 0V

Measuring <SIGNAL>EDP_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> gives me 0V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
First you need an image before even looking at the backlight circuit. Does L8300 get a pulse of 5V while powering on. Check it while powering on and it should go to 5V for a while. If it then drops off it means no LCD was detected.
Was this liquid damage? Tried an external screen?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message: No liquid damage reported or found. L8300 gets a split second pulse where the meter shows 0L but then 0V immediately after on both pins. An external screen receives no signal from either Thunderbolt port.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message: Does this even chime? Maybe you are addressing a no lcd issue when in reality you should be looking for a no brain issue.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
No video over DisplayPort (Thunderbolt) could indicate an issue with the CPU, I think even without display connected this should work, but I have not verified this myself.

Also to measure L8300 put your multimeter on Voltage mode and on a high enough range (One that can probe 5V). It shoudn't show OL as that would mean it peaks on a high voltage.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message: Inspect connector/cable and try a known good LCD assembly. 2012-14 all work for testing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
The meter figures out the range itself, it picks up 5V as well as 60V or 0.020 mV and displays it properly. That said I don't have years of experience using a meter so.. that's just my observations.
Would the Mac still chime if there's a CPU issue?

A known-good display was tried before it was shipped to me and it had the same problem. All I have is 13" 2013 displays to try, would that work? I know the techs at the shop this came from, they have the skill to properly troubleshoot so I don't doubt their KG equipment or methods. Once they believe it's board related they ship it to me, they don't tinker with it themselves. The connector and cable look good as new. The connector pins are all firmly connected to the board, the inside looks clean and ok as well.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
I put the machine back together as I need some space for other repairs right now.
Aimed a bright LED light at the center of the screen and powered on. For a split second I see white lines on the screen, not visible without the LED light pointed at it. This is the same time as the chime is heard, maybe but barely before. Screenshot of a video recording I did:
[ATTACH type="full" width="200px"]26258._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
Auto ranging meters are stupidly slow. No way to catch pulsing rails on these things.
First thing is still to test with a known good LCD. Just dig up a few cracked test LCDs. Also check for any knocked off caps/resistors in the data lines to the LCD.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message: KG display en route. Should get here same time as fine meter probes. To be continued.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image no backlight
threads.message:
KG display arrived, Mac is in perfect health. Lesson learned; test everything myself even if others have tested it already.
Thanks for the help along the way  guys :)

(I don't know how to mark posts as solved, can an admin do so pls?)
